para.paratext: In Norfolk Southern Railway Co. v. Thompson,[1] the Georgia Court of Appeals held, in a slip-and-fall case, that evidence of injuries sustained by other parties on prior occasions could be admitted to show that the defendant had notice of the dangerous condition and was negligent in allowing it to continue.

In Cooper Tire & Rubber Co. v. Crosby,[2] the Georgia Supreme Court explained that the proponent must first show that there is a “substantial similarity” between the other transactions, occurrences, or claims and the claim at issue before evidence of similar accidents is admissible to show notice of a product defect, design flaw, or lack of appropriate warning. Thus, a party seeking to introduce similar incidents into evidence in a products liability case must show that the products share a common design, suffer from a common defect, and the defects share the same causation.[3]

This test was applied in Colp v. Ford Motor Co.,[4] a products liability suit involving a minivan sliding door which fell off during a crash, causing the plaintiff's husband to be ejected and suffer severe brain damage. The Georgia Court of Appeals concluded that prior incidents demonstrating failure of the minivans' sliding doors when the minivans rolled over were not substantially similar to this accident in which the passenger was ejected during a side-impact collision.

Evidence that a manufacturer's product had previously been recalled is admissible to prove the product is defective if the product was the exact type involved in the lawsuit. Also, evidence of other incidents involving the product at issue is admissible and relevant to the issues of notice of a defect and punitive damages provided that there is a showing of substantial similarity between the two incidents.[5]

Evidence of other injuries involving the same product is also admissible and relevant to the issue of notice of defect and punitive damages.[6] The Court of Appeals allowed evidence of 17 other incidents where Jeeps were involved in rear-end collisions to prove that Chrysler knew there was a defect with the placement of the fuel tank, and yet failed to warn the public. In a product liability case, evidence of other incidents involving the product is admissible provided it is substantially similar. Thus, the plaintiff must show that the incidents shared a common design, common defect, and common causation. In the case at hand, the court found there was a common design even though it involved different models, and it found common causation, since the incidents all involved rear-end collisions.[7]

In premises liability cases, prior crimes may be used to show the defendant was on notice of a dangerous situation on or around his property. Evidence showing the landlord's property is located in a high crime area is admissible on the issue of foreseeable criminal activity. In Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority v. Allen,[8] the Georgia Court of Appeals set out specific guidelines for determining admissibility of similar transaction evidence in these cases: (1) past crimes must show a reasonable risk of criminal activity at the location in question, (2) past crimes must be sufficient to attract the defendant's attention, (3) past crimes must be substantially similar to the crime at issue, and (4) substantial similarity is to be determined on a case-by-case basis without the necessity of showing the prior crimes are identical. Following these guidelines, the court held that prior daylight armed robberies were sufficiently similar to an armed robbery and rape which occurred at the same location after dark because such crimes were similar “in the obvious respect that each involved a criminal assault against a … patron in the [same] parking lot.” Additionally, crimes as far back as three and one-half years earlier were admissible because they showed “a pattern of increasing criminal activity at the location in question.”[9]

In Lau's Corp. Inc. v. Haskins[10] and Savannah College of Art and Design, Inc. v. Roe,[11] the court expanded the type of prior crimes evidence admissible in premises liability cases involving criminal assault by a third party. Previously, only prior “substantially similar” crimes were admitted to show that the defendant had a duty to exercise care to guard patrons against the risk posed by criminal activity. After these cases, however, evidence that a defendant's business is in a high crime area is not limited to evidence of prior “substantially similar” crimes. Although the plaintiff in Lau was the victim of an assault, the court allowed evidence of prior burglaries in the neighborhood to show the assault occurred in a high crime area. Subsequently, the Georgia Supreme Court held in Savannah College that evidence showing defendant's business is in a general “high crime” area is admissible on the issue of the business owner's duty to protect patrons from criminal activity when coupled with evidence of a recent prior substantially similar crime.[12] However, in Savannah College, there had been no prior substantially similar assault in the area and the defendant had no affirmative duty to protect patrons against such violent criminal assaults.[13]

In Sturbridge Partners, Ltd. v. Walker,[14] the Supreme Court held that two previous daylight burglaries in unoccupied apartments in the same complex in which plaintiff lived were sufficient to establish the foresee ability of someone breaking into plaintiff's apartment to rape her. The Court expressly overruled Savannah College of Art and Design v. Roe[15] to the extent that it may hold that prior property crimes cannot put a landowner on notice of potential future crimes against individuals, and noted that a landlord would necessarily use the same safeguards against all burglars, regardless of whether they committed assaults or stole property.

Similar transaction evidence is admissible in employment discrimination cases to show that the employer had “notice” of an employee's improper behavior. In Ferman v. Bailey,[16] the Georgia Court of Appeals concluded that evidence of an employee's harassment of other employees was admissible in plaintiff's claim of negligent hiring and retention because it tended to show that the employer should have known that the employee posed a risk of committing the same type of harassing behavior against the plaintiff.
